segment.source: Begin by reviewing your existing corporate security policies as they relate to disk encryption software.
segment.target: Begin by reviewing your existing corporate security policies as they relate to disk encryption software.

segment.source: If your organization is not currently using disk encryption software, none of these policies will exist.
segment.target: If your organization is not currently using disk encryption software, none of these policies will exist.

segment.source: BitLocker helps prevent unauthorized access to data on lost or stolen computers by:
segment.target: BitLocker helps prevent unauthorized access to data on lost or stolen computers by:

segment.source: Encrypting the entire Windows operating system volume on the hard disk.
segment.target: Encrypting the entire Windows operating system volume on the hard disk.

segment.source: Verifying the boot process integrity.
segment.target: Verifying the boot process integrity.

segment.source: The trusted platform module (TPM)is a hardware component installed in many newer computers by the computer manufacturers.
segment.target: The trusted platform module (TPM)is a hardware component installed in many newer computers by the computer manufacturers.

segment.source: It works with BitLocker to help protect user data and to ensure that a computer has not been tampered with while the system was offline.
segment.target: It works with BitLocker to help protect user data and to ensure that a computer has not been tampered with while the system was offline.

segment.source: In addition, BitLocker offers the option to lock the normal startup process until the user supplies a personal identification number (PIN) or inserts a removable USB device, such as a flash drive, that contains a startup key.
segment.target: In addition, BitLocker offers the option to lock the normal startup process until the user supplies a personal identification number (PIN) or inserts a removable USB device, such as a flash drive, that contains a startup key.

segment.source: These additional security measures provide multifactor authentication and assurance that the computer will not start or resume from hibernation until the correct PIN or startup key is presented.
segment.target: These additional security measures provide multifactor authentication and assurance that the computer will not start or resume from hibernation until the correct PIN or startup key is presented.

segment.source: On computers that do not have a TPM version 1.2 or higher, you can still use BitLocker to encrypt the Windows operating system volume.
segment.target: On computers that do not have a TPM version 1.2 or higher, you can still use BitLocker to encrypt the Windows operating system volume.

segment.source: However, this implementation will require the user to insert a USB startup key to start the computer or resume from hibernation, and does not provide the pre-startup system integrity verification offered by BitLocker working with a TPM.
segment.target: However, this implementation will require the user to insert a USB startup key to start the computer or resume from hibernation, and does not provide the pre-startup system integrity verification offered by BitLocker working with a TPM.

segment.source: Endorsement keys
segment.target: Endorsement keys

segment.source: For a TPM to be usable by BitLocker, it must contain an endorsement key, which is an RSA key pair.
segment.target: For a TPM to be usable by BitLocker, it must contain an endorsement key, which is an RSA key pair.

segment.source: The private half of the key pair is held inside the TPM and is never revealed or accessible outside the TPM.
segment.target: The private half of the key pair is held inside the TPM and is never revealed or accessible outside the TPM.

segment.source: If the TPM does not contain an endorsement key, BitLocker will force the TPM to generate one automatically as part of BitLocker setup.
segment.target: If the TPM does not contain an endorsement key, BitLocker will force the TPM to generate one automatically as part of BitLocker setup.

segment.source: An endorsement key can be created at various points in the TPM’s lifecycle, but needs to be created only once for the lifetime of the TPM.
segment.target: An endorsement key can be created at various points in the TPM’s lifecycle, but needs to be created only once for the lifetime of the TPM.

segment.source: If an endorsement key does not exist for the TPM, it must be created before TPM ownership can be taken.
segment.target: If an endorsement key does not exist for the TPM, it must be created before TPM ownership can be taken.

segment.source: Launching the BitLocker Setup wizard prompts for the authentication method to be used (password and smart card are available for data volumes).
segment.target: Launching the BitLocker Setup wizard prompts for the authentication method to be used (password and smart card are available for data volumes).

segment.source: Once the method is chosen and the recovery key is saved, you are asked to choose the drive encryption type, either Used Disk Space Only or Full drive encryption.
segment.target: Once the method is chosen and the recovery key is saved, you are asked to choose the drive encryption type, either Used Disk Space Only or Full drive encryption.

segment.source: Used Disk Space Only means that only the portion of the drive that contains data will be encrypted, unused space will remain unencrypted.
segment.target: Used Disk Space Only means that only the portion of the drive that contains data will be encrypted, unused space will remain unencrypted.

segment.source: This causes the encryption process to be much faster, especially for new PCs and data drives.
segment.target: This causes the encryption process to be much faster, especially for new PCs and data drives.

segment.source: When BitLocker is enabled with this method as data is added to the drive the portion of the drive used will be encrypted, so there is never unencrypted data stored on the drive.
segment.target: When BitLocker is enabled with this method as data is added to the drive the portion of the drive used will be encrypted, so there is never unencrypted data stored on the drive.

segment.source: Full drive encryption means that the entire drive will be encrypted, regardless of whether data is stored on it or not.
segment.target: Full drive encryption means that the entire drive will be encrypted, regardless of whether data is stored on it or not.

segment.source: This is useful for drives that have been repurposed and may contain data remnants from their previous use.
segment.target: This is useful for drives that have been repurposed and may contain data remnants from their previous use.

segment.source: Active Directory Domain Services considerations
segment.target: Active Directory Domain Services considerations

segment.source: BitLocker integrates with Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) to provide centralized key management.
segment.target: BitLocker integrates with Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) to provide centralized key management.

segment.source: By default, no recovery information is backed up to Active Directory.
segment.target: By default, no recovery information is backed up to Active Directory.

segment.source: Administrators can configure Group Policy settings to enable backup of BitLocker or TPM recovery information.
segment.target: Administrators can configure Group Policy settings to enable backup of BitLocker or TPM recovery information.

segment.source: Before configuring these settings verify that access permissions have been granted to perform the backup.
segment.target: Before configuring these settings verify that access permissions have been granted to perform the backup.

segment.source: By default, domain administrators are the only users that will have access to BitLocker recovery information.
segment.target: By default, domain administrators are the only users that will have access to BitLocker recovery information.

segment.source: When you plan your support process, define what parts of your organization need access to BitLocker recovery information.
segment.target: When you plan your support process, define what parts of your organization need access to BitLocker recovery information.

segment.source: Use this information to define how the appropriate rights will be delegated in your AD DS environment.
segment.target: Use this information to define how the appropriate rights will be delegated in your AD DS environment.

segment.source: It is a best practice to require backup of recovery information for both the TPM and BitLocker to AD DS.
segment.target: It is a best practice to require backup of recovery information for both the TPM and BitLocker to AD DS.

segment.source: You can implement this practice by configuring the Group Policy settings below for your BitLocker-protected computers.
segment.target: You can implement this practice by configuring the Group Policy settings below for your BitLocker-protected computers.

segment.source: The following recovery data will be saved for each computer object:
segment.target: The following recovery data will be saved for each computer object:

segment.source: Recovery password
segment.target: Recovery password

segment.source: A 48-digit recovery password used to recover a BitLocker-protected volume.
segment.target: A 48-digit recovery password used to recover a BitLocker-protected volume.

segment.source: Users enter this password to unlock a volume when BitLocker enters recovery mode.
segment.target: Users enter this password to unlock a volume when BitLocker enters recovery mode.

segment.source: Key package data
segment.target: Key package data

segment.source: With this key package and the recovery password, you will be able decrypt portions of a BitLocker-protected volume if the disk is severely damaged.
segment.target: With this key package and the recovery password, you will be able decrypt portions of a BitLocker-protected volume if the disk is severely damaged.

segment.source: Each key package will only work with the volume it was created on, which can be identified by the corresponding volume ID.
segment.target: Each key package will only work with the volume it was created on, which can be identified by the corresponding volume ID.

segment.source: TPM owner authorization password hash
segment.target: TPM owner authorization password hash

segment.source: When ownership of the TPM is taken a hash of the ownership password can be taken and stored in AD DS.
segment.target: When ownership of the TPM is taken a hash of the ownership password can be taken and stored in AD DS.

segment.source: This information can then be used to reset ownership of the TPM.
segment.target: This information can then be used to reset ownership of the TPM.

segment.source: Starting in Windows 8, a change to how the TPM owner authorization value is stored in AD DS was implemented in the AD DS schema.
segment.target: Starting in Windows 8, a change to how the TPM owner authorization value is stored in AD DS was implemented in the AD DS schema.

segment.source: The TPM owner authorization value is now stored in a separate object which is linked to the Computer object.
segment.target: The TPM owner authorization value is now stored in a separate object which is linked to the Computer object.

segment.source: This value was stored as a property in the Computer object itself for the default Windows Server 2008 R2 and later schemas.
segment.target: This value was stored as a property in the Computer object itself for the default Windows Server 2008 R2 and later schemas.

segment.source: To take advantage of this integration, you must upgrade your domain controllers to Windows Server 2012 or extend the Active Directory schema and configure BitLocker-specific Group Policy objects.
segment.target: To take advantage of this integration, you must upgrade your domain controllers to Windows Server 2012 or extend the Active Directory schema and configure BitLocker-specific Group Policy objects.

segment.source: Note: The account that you use to update the Active Directory schema must be a member of the Schema Admins group.
segment.target: Note: The account that you use to update the Active Directory schema must be a member of the Schema Admins group.

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 domain controllers have the default schema to backup TPM owner authorization information in the separate object.
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 domain controllers have the default schema to backup TPM owner authorization information in the separate object.

segment.source: If you are not upgrading your domain controller to Windows Server 2012 you need to extend the schema to support this change.
segment.target: If you are not upgrading your domain controller to Windows Server 2012 you need to extend the schema to support this change.

segment.source: To support Windows 8 and later computers that are managed by a Windows Server 2003 or Windows 2008 domain controller
segment.target: To support Windows 8 and later computers that are managed by a Windows Server 2003 or Windows 2008 domain controller

segment.source: There are two schema extensions that you can copy down and add to your AD DS schema:
segment.target: There are two schema extensions that you can copy down and add to your AD DS schema:

segment.source: TpmSchemaExtension.ldf
segment.target: TpmSchemaExtension.ldf

segment.source: This schema extension brings parity with the Windows Server 2012 schema.
segment.target: This schema extension brings parity with the Windows Server 2012 schema.

segment.source: With this change, the TPM owner authorization information is stored in a separate TPM object linked to the corresponding computer object.
segment.target: With this change, the TPM owner authorization information is stored in a separate TPM object linked to the corresponding computer object.

segment.source: Only the Computer object that has created the TPM object can update it.
segment.target: Only the Computer object that has created the TPM object can update it.

segment.source: This means that any subsequent updates to the TPM objects will not succeed in dual boot scenarios or scenarios where the computer is reimaged resulting in a new AD computer object being created.
segment.target: This means that any subsequent updates to the TPM objects will not succeed in dual boot scenarios or scenarios where the computer is reimaged resulting in a new AD computer object being created.

segment.source: To support such scenarios, an update to the schema was created.
segment.target: To support such scenarios, an update to the schema was created.

segment.source: TpmSchemaExtensionACLChanges.ldf
segment.target: TpmSchemaExtensionACLChanges.ldf

segment.source: This schema update modifies the ACLs on the TPM object to be less restrictive so that any subsequent operating system which takes ownership of the computer object can update the owner authorization value in AD DS.
segment.target: This schema update modifies the ACLs on the TPM object to be less restrictive so that any subsequent operating system which takes ownership of the computer object can update the owner authorization value in AD DS.

segment.source: However, this is less secure as any computer in the domain can now update the OwnerAuth of the TPM object (although it cannot read the OwnerAuth) and DOS attacks can be made from within the enterprise.
segment.target: However, this is less secure as any computer in the domain can now update the OwnerAuth of the TPM object (although it cannot read the OwnerAuth) and DOS attacks can be made from within the enterprise.

segment.source: The recommended mitigation in such a scenario is to do regular backup of TPM objects and enable auditing to track changes for these objects.
segment.target: The recommended mitigation in such a scenario is to do regular backup of TPM objects and enable auditing to track changes for these objects.

segment.source: To download the schema extensions, see AD DS schema extensions to support TPM backup.
segment.target: To download the schema extensions, see AD DS schema extensions to support TPM backup.

segment.source: If you have a Windows Server 2012 domain controller in your environment, the schema extensions are already in place and do not need to be updated.
segment.target: If you have a Windows Server 2012 domain controller in your environment, the schema extensions are already in place and do not need to be updated.

segment.source: Caution: To configure Group Policy objects to backup TPM and BitLocker information in AD DS at least one of the domain controllers in your forest must be running at least Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: Caution: To configure Group Policy objects to backup TPM and BitLocker information in AD DS at least one of the domain controllers in your forest must be running at least Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: If Active Directory backup of the TPM owner authorization value is enabled in an environment without the required schema extensions, the TPM provisioning will fail and the TPM will remain in a Not Ready state for computers running Windows 8 and later.
segment.target: If Active Directory backup of the TPM owner authorization value is enabled in an environment without the required schema extensions, the TPM provisioning will fail and the TPM will remain in a Not Ready state for computers running Windows 8 and later.

segment.source: Setting the correct permissions in AD DS
segment.target: Setting the correct permissions in AD DS

segment.source: To initialize the TPM successfully so that you can turn on BitLocker requires that the correct permissions for the SELF account in be set in AD DS for the ms-TPMOwnerInformation attribute.
segment.target: To initialize the TPM successfully so that you can turn on BitLocker requires that the correct permissions for the SELF account in be set in AD DS for the ms-TPMOwnerInformation attribute.

segment.source: The following steps detail setting these permissions as required by BitLocker:
segment.target: The following steps detail setting these permissions as required by BitLocker:

segment.source: Open Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: Open Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: Select the organizational unit (OU) which contains the computer accounts that will have BitLocker turned on.
segment.target: Select the organizational unit (OU) which contains the computer accounts that will have BitLocker turned on.

segment.source: Right-click the OU and click Delegate Control to open the Delegation of Control wizard.
segment.target: Right-click the OU and click Delegate Control to open the Delegation of Control wizard.

segment.source: Click Next to go to the Users or Groups page and then click Add.
segment.target: Click Next to go to the Users or Groups page and then click Add.

segment.source: In the Select Users, Computers, or Groups dialog box, type SELF as the object name and then click OK Once the object has been validated you will be returned to the Users or Groups wizard page and the SELF account will be listed.
segment.target: In the Select Users, Computers, or Groups dialog box, type SELF as the object name and then click OK Once the object has been validated you will be returned to the Users or Groups wizard page and the SELF account will be listed.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the Tasks to Delegate page, choose Create a custom task to delegate and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Tasks to Delegate page, choose Create a custom task to delegate and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Active Directory Object Type page, choose Only the following objects in the folder and then check Computer Objects and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Active Directory Object Type page, choose Only the following objects in the folder and then check Computer Objects and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Permissions page, for Show these permissions, check General, Property-specific, and Creation/deletion of specific child objects.
segment.target: On the Permissions page, for Show these permissions, check General, Property-specific, and Creation/deletion of specific child objects.

segment.source: Scroll down the Permissions list and check both Write msTPM-OwnerInformation and Write msTPM-TpmInformationForComputer then click Next.
segment.target: Scroll down the Permissions list and check both Write msTPM-OwnerInformation and Write msTPM-TpmInformationForComputer then click Next.

segment.source: Click Finish to apply the permissions settings.
segment.target: Click Finish to apply the permissions settings.

segment.source: FIPS support for recovery password protector
segment.target: FIPS support for recovery password protector

segment.source: Functionality introduced in Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1, allows BitLocker to be fully functional in FIPS mode.
segment.target: Functionality introduced in Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1, allows BitLocker to be fully functional in FIPS mode.

segment.source: Note: The United States Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) defines security and interoperability requirements for computer systems that are used by the U.S. federal government.
segment.target: Note: The United States Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) defines security and interoperability requirements for computer systems that are used by the U.S. federal government.

segment.source: The FIPS 140 standard defines approved cryptographic algorithms.
segment.target: The FIPS 140 standard defines approved cryptographic algorithms.

segment.source: The FIPS 140 standard also sets forth requirements for key generation and for key management.
segment.target: The FIPS 140 standard also sets forth requirements for key generation and for key management.

segment.source: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) uses the Cryptographic Module Validation Program (CMVP) to determine whether a particular implementation of a cryptographic algorithm is compliant with the FIPS 140 standard.
segment.target: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) uses the Cryptographic Module Validation Program (CMVP) to determine whether a particular implementation of a cryptographic algorithm is compliant with the FIPS 140 standard.

segment.source: An implementation of a cryptographic algorithm is considered FIPS 140-compliant only if it has been submitted for and has passed NIST validation.
segment.target: An implementation of a cryptographic algorithm is considered FIPS 140-compliant only if it has been submitted for and has passed NIST validation.

segment.source: An algorithm that has not been submitted cannot be considered FIPS-compliant even if the implementation produces identical data as a validated implementation of the same algorithm.
segment.target: An algorithm that has not been submitted cannot be considered FIPS-compliant even if the implementation produces identical data as a validated implementation of the same algorithm.

segment.source: Prior to these supported versions of Windows, when Windows was in FIPS mode, BitLocker prevented the creation or use of recovery passwords and instead forced the user to use recovery keys.
segment.target: Prior to these supported versions of Windows, when Windows was in FIPS mode, BitLocker prevented the creation or use of recovery passwords and instead forced the user to use recovery keys.

segment.source: For more information about these issues, see the support article kb947249.
segment.target: For more information about these issues, see the support article kb947249.

segment.source: But on computers running these supported systems with BitLocker enabled:
segment.target: But on computers running these supported systems with BitLocker enabled:

segment.source: FIPS-compliant recovery password protectors can be created when Windows is in FIPS mode.
segment.target: FIPS-compliant recovery password protectors can be created when Windows is in FIPS mode.

segment.source: These protectors use the FIPS 140 NIST SP800-132 algorithm.
segment.target: These protectors use the FIPS 140 NIST SP800-132 algorithm.

segment.source: Recovery passwords created in FIPS mode on Windows 8.1 can be distinguished from recovery passwords created on other systems.
segment.target: Recovery passwords created in FIPS mode on Windows 8.1 can be distinguished from recovery passwords created on other systems.

segment.source: Recovery unlock using the FIPS-compliant algorithm based recovery password protector work in all cases that currently work for recovery passwords.
segment.target: Recovery unlock using the FIPS-compliant algorithm based recovery password protector work in all cases that currently work for recovery passwords.

segment.source: When FIPS-compliant recovery passwords unlock volumes, the volume is unlocked to allow read/write access even while in FIPS mode.
segment.target: When FIPS-compliant recovery passwords unlock volumes, the volume is unlocked to allow read/write access even while in FIPS mode.

segment.source: FIPS-compliant recovery password protectors can be exported and stored in AD a while in FIPS mode.
segment.target: FIPS-compliant recovery password protectors can be exported and stored in AD a while in FIPS mode.

segment.source: The BitLocker Group Policy settings for recovery passwords work the same for all Windows versions that support BitLocker, whether in FIPs mode or not.
segment.target: The BitLocker Group Policy settings for recovery passwords work the same for all Windows versions that support BitLocker, whether in FIPs mode or not.

segment.source: However, you cannot use recovery passwords generated on a system in FIPS mode for systems earlier than Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1.
segment.target: However, you cannot use recovery passwords generated on a system in FIPS mode for systems earlier than Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1.

segment.source: Recovery passwords created on Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1 are incompatible with BitLocker on operating systems prior to Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1; so recovery keys should be used instead.
segment.target: Recovery passwords created on Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1 are incompatible with BitLocker on operating systems prior to Windows Server 2012 R2 and Windows 8.1; so recovery keys should be used instead.
